title: 108_hr1106
content:
The Act titled the "Fremont-Madison Conveyance Act" defines terms like "District" and "Secretary" before discussing the conveyance of facilities. The Secretary of the Interior is required to convey water distribution and drainage system components to the Fremont-Madison Irrigation District in Idaho as per the memorandum of agreement. If the conveyance is not completed, a report must be submitted. If the Secretary fails to complete any conveyance required by September 13, 2004, a report must be submitted to Congress explaining the delay and providing a new completion date. SEC. 4. COSTS. The Secretary will require the District to pay administrative costs and the net present value of remaining obligations for the conveyance of facilities under section 3 and 2, respectively. The District must pay administrative costs and remaining obligations for facility conveyance. Amounts received by the United States will be deposited into the Reclamation Fund. The Secretary will convey the Teton Exchange Wells, including a water permit and equipment, to the District. The water service contract between the Secretary and the District is extended until all conditions in the Act are met. SEC. 6. ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW

Before conveyance, the Secretary must complete all environmental reviews and analyses as outlined in the Memorandum of Agreement referenced in section 3(a).

SEC. 7. LIABILITY

Upon conveyance, the United States will not be liable for damages arising from the conveyed facilities, except for negligence committed prior to the conveyance date. This section does not increase the liability of the United States beyond what is currently provided in chapter 171 of title 28, United States Code. SEC. 8. WATER SUPPLY TO DISTRICT LANDS.

The acreage eligible for water from the Minidoka and Teton Basin Projects in the District is increased to include all current and annexed lands. This increase does not affect existing water contracts or State water law.

SEC. 9. DROUGHT MANAGEMENT PLANNING. Within 60 days of enactment, the Secretary will collaborate with stakeholders in the Henry's Fork watershed to initiate a drought management planning process for all water uses. Within 18 months, a final drought management plan will be submitted to Congress. The Act does not affect existing rights, including those of the Shoshone-Bannock Tribes to water based on treaties or laws. Conveyances under the Act do not impact contracts or state laws regarding water rights.
